title: Your body's real age

multiple-choice.question: How often are the hairs on your head replaced?
What happens to the lining of your stomach and intestines over time?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes thicker and more resilient

options.label: B
options.text: It remains the same throughout your life

options.label: C
options.text: It gets replaced every few days

multiple-choice.question: How often is your outer layer of skin completely renewed?
What happens to your red blood cells over time?

options.label: A
options.text: They remain the same throughout your life

options.label: C
options.text: They are completely replaced every four months

multiple-choice.question: How often is your skeleton replaced?
What happens to your fat cells when you gain and lose weight?

options.label: A
options.text: They are replaced with new cells

multiple-choice.question: Which part of your body stays with you from birth to death?
What happens to the connections between neurons in your brain over time?
Which part of your eye remains the same since birth?
How old is your body, according to the video?

options.label: C
options.text: Some of it is brand-new and some of it is as old as you are

title: What you don't know about who you will become

multiple-choice.question: What is the main question that the psychologist is trying to answer in this talk?

options.label: A
options.text: Why do people make decisions that they later regret?

options.label: B
options.text: How can people make better decisions?

options.label: C
options.text: What is the most important factor in decision-making?

options.label: D
options.text: How can people change their personalities?

multiple-choice.question: According to the psychologist, what is the "end of history" illusion?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that people's values and personalities will not change in the future.

options.label: B
options.text: The idea that people's values and personalities will change rapidly in the future.

options.label: C
options.text: The idea that people's values and personalities will change slowly in the future.

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that people's values and personalities will change in unpredictable ways.

multiple-choice.question: What did the study on personal values find?

options.label: A
options.text: That people's values change rapidly as they age.

options.label: B
options.text: That people's values change slowly as they age.

options.label: C
options.text: That people vastly underestimate how much their values will change in the next 10 years.

options.label: D
options.text: That people's values remain stable throughout their lives.

multiple-choice.question: What are the five fundamental dimensions of personality, according to psychologists?

options.label: A
options.text: Neuroticism, openness to experience, agreeableness, extraversion, and conscientiousness.

options.label: B
options.text: Intelligence, creativity, emotional stability, and physical attractiveness.

options.label: D
options.text: Motivation, self-esteem, self-confidence, and emotional intelligence.

multiple-choice.question: What did the study on personality find?

options.label: A
options.text: That people's personalities change rapidly as they age.

options.label: B
options.text: That people's personalities change slowly as they age.

options.label: C
options.text: That people vastly underestimate how much their personalities will change in the next 10 years.

options.label: D
options.text: That people's personalities remain stable throughout their lives.

multiple-choice.question: What is the consequence of the "end of history" illusion?

options.label: B
options.text: That people are more confident in their decisions.

options.label: C
options.text: That people overpay for the opportunity to indulge their current preferences.

options.label: D
options.text: That people are less likely to change their values and personalities.

multiple-choice.question: Why do people overpay for the opportunity to indulge their current preferences?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are afraid of change.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are overconfident in their decisions.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they overestimate the stability of their preferences.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are trying to avoid regret.

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason for the "end of history" illusion, according to the psychologist?

options.label: A
options.text: The ease of remembering versus the difficulty of imagining.

options.label: B
options.text: The fear of change versus the desire for stability.

options.label: C
options.text: The overconfidence in one's decisions versus the uncertainty of the future.

options.label: D
options.text: The lack of self-awareness versus the presence of self-deception.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main message of the talk?

options.label: A
options.text: That people should be more confident in their decisions.

options.label: B
options.text: That people should be more cautious in their decisions.

options.label: C
options.text: That people are works in progress that mistakenly think they're finished.

options.label: D
options.text: That people should try to avoid change.

multiple-choice.question: What is the one constant in our lives, according to the psychologist?

title: How smart are orangutans? - Lu Gao

multiple-choice.question: What was unique about Fu Manchu, an orangutan at the Omaha Zoo in the 1960s?

options.label: A
options.text: He was a performer in the zoo's shows.

options.label: B
options.text: He was known for his striking red hair.

options.label: C
options.text: He was able to pick the lock of his enclosure using a metal wire.

options.label: D
options.text: He was the largest orangutan in the zoo.

multiple-choice.question: How long does an orangutan mother typically wait before having another baby?
What is unique about the bond between an orangutan mother and her child?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the shortest in the animal kingdom.

options.label: B
options.text: It is the most aggressive in the animal kingdom.

options.label: C
options.text: It is the most extended in the animal kingdom, next to humans.

options.label: D
options.text: It is the weakest in the animal kingdom.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: A branch to use as a fly swatter

options.label: C
options.text: A leaf to use as a shelter

options.label: D
options.text: A stick to use as a fishing rod

multiple-choice.question: What has research shown about orangutans' cognitive abilities?

options.label: A
options.text: They are unable to recognize their own reflections.

options.label: B
options.text: They are unable to display foresight and planning.

options.label: C
options.text: They are self-aware and display remarkable foresight, planning, and cognition.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only able to solve simple problems.

multiple-choice.question: What is a major threat to orangutans in the wild?
Why do poachers kill orangutan mothers?

options.label: B
options.text: To sell their babies as exotic pets

options.label: C
options.text: To use their body parts for traditional medicine

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of special forest schools for orphaned orangutans?

options.label: A
options.text: To train them for circus performances

options.label: B
options.text: To rehabilitate them and teach them essential life skills

What is required to prevent the extinction of orangutans?

options.label: A
options.text: Only conservation efforts by governments and organizations

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: Why can't we just print money to pay off debt?

multiple-choice.question: Why can't countries just print more money to pay off their debts?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it would lead to a decrease in the value of their currency.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it would lead to an increase in the value of their currency.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it would have no effect on the economy.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is not physically possible to print that much money.

multiple-choice.question: What is inflation?

options.label: A
options.text: A decrease in the general level of prices.

options.label: B
options.text: A persistent, substantial rise in the general level of prices related to an increase in the volume of money.

multiple-choice.question: What gives money its value?

options.label: A
options.text: The intrinsic value of the material it is made of.

options.label: B
options.text: The value assigned to it by the government.

options.label: C
options.text: The fact that people believe it has value.

options.label: D
options.text: The rarity of the material it is made of.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Tinkerbell effect?

options.label: B
options.text: A phenomenon where something only exists because people believe it exists.

multiple-choice.question: What type of money is used by almost every country in the world today?
What happens when a country prints too much money?

options.label: A
options.text: The value of their currency increases.

options.label: B
options.text: The value of their currency decreases.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a country that suffered from hyperinflation due to printing too much money?
What is the term for inflation that exceeds 50%?

title: Does this look white to you?

multiple-choice.question: What happens when you stare at the circle at the center of a group of dots and don't move your eyes?

options.label: A
options.text: You see a blue dot that is actually there.

options.label: B
options.text: You see a blue dot that is not actually there.

options.label: C
options.text: You see a red dot that is actually there.

options.label: D
options.text: You see a red dot that is not actually there.

multiple-choice.question: What color do you see when you mix red and green light?
What is the reason why you see yellow when you mix red and green light?

options.label: A
options.text: Because there is a cone for yellow light in the retina.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the red and green cones respond and the brain combines the responses to say it's yellow.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the blue cone responds and the brain says it's yellow.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the red cone responds and the brain says it's yellow.

multiple-choice.question: How does an LCD screen trick you into seeing yellow?

options.label: A
options.text: By shining yellow light on your eyes.

options.label: B
options.text: By shining red and green light on your eyes, which the brain combines to say it's yellow.

options.label: C
options.text: By shining blue light on your eyes.

options.label: D
options.text: By shining red light on your eyes.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when you mix two complementary colors of light?

options.label: A
options.text: You get a darker brownish color.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the blue color appear when you stare at a yellow star and then switch to a white screen?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the blue cone is excited by the white light.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the red and green cones are dulled and the blue cone sends a stronger signal to the brain.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the yellow cone is excited by the white light.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the red cone is excited by the white light.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between complementary colors in paint and light?

options.label: A
options.text: Complementary colors in paint and light are the same.

options.label: B
options.text: Complementary colors in paint absorb more colors, while in light, they add up to white.

options.label: C
options.text: Complementary colors in paint add up to white, while in light, they absorb more colors.

options.label: D
options.text: Complementary colors in paint and light are opposite.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of cones in perceiving color?

options.label: A
options.text: Cones perceive color by responding to different wavelengths of light.

options.label: B
options.text: Cones perceive color by responding to different intensities of light.

options.label: C
options.text: Cones perceive color by responding to different frequencies of light.

options.label: D
options.text: Cones perceive color by responding to different amplitudes of light.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when you shine red, green, and blue light on your eyes?

options.label: A
options.text: You see red, green, and blue.

multiple-choice.question: Why do RGB screens use red, green, and blue pixels to create images?

options.label: A
options.text: Because red, green, and blue are the primary colors of paint.

options.label: B
options.text: Because red, green, and blue are the primary colors of light.

options.label: C
options.text: Because red, green, and blue are the secondary colors of paint.

options.label: D
options.text: Because red, green, and blue are the secondary colors of light.

title: Our natural sleep cycle is nothing like what we do now

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason for the development of internal clocks in plants and animals?

options.label: B
options.text: To adapt to changes in light and darkness

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the internal clock in humans?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: They go to bed earlier every day

options.label: C
options.text: They get up a little bit later every day

options.text: They sleep during the day and are awake at night

options.label: B
options.text: We are experiencing true wakefulness for the first time

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: We are sleeping more soundly than ever before

options.label: C
options.text: Due to the variations in daylight hours

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: We should prioritize productivity over sleep

options.label: D

title: Are spotty fruits and vegetables safe to eat? - Elizabeth Brauer

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated value of fruits and vegetables wasted by American retailers and shoppers in 2010?
What percentage of the produce on the market is wasted due to cosmetic problems and perceived spoilage?
What are the spots on fruits and vegetables evidence of?

options.label: C
options.text: An epic battle between plants and microbes

multiple-choice.question: Are the microbes that cause spots on fruits and vegetables typically bad for human health?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, they can cause serious illnesses

options.label: B
options.text: No, they are almost never bad for human health

options.label: C
options.text: Maybe, it depends on the type of microbe

options.label: D
options.text: Only if the produce is not washed properly

multiple-choice.question: How do microbes typically reach plants?

options.label: C
options.text: By getting splashed onto the plant during watering or fertilization

multiple-choice.question: What is the target of pathogens that attack fruits and vegetables?

options.label: C
options.text: The delicious sugars and nutrients inside the plant

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the bacterial pathogen that can cause spots on tomatoes?
What is the effect of the toxin coronatine on plants?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes the plant's stomata close

options.label: B
options.text: It makes the plant's stomata open up

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why some fruits and vegetables develop mushy blemishes?

options.label: B
options.text: Because of microbial attack after the fruit is detached from the plant

multiple-choice.question: What is the best way to avoid getting sick from eating fruits and vegetables?

options.label: A
options.text: Avoid eating spotty or blemished produce

options.label: B
options.text: Wash the produce thoroughly before eating

options.label: C
options.text: Only eat produce that is certified organic

options.label: D
options.text: Only eat produce that is grown locally

title: What is the biggest single-celled organism? - Murry Gans

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why unicellular organisms are generally small in size?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they lack the necessary resources to grow larger.

options.label: B
options.text: Because their surface area and volume increase at different rates, limiting their ability to exchange resources and waste.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are less complex than multicellular organisms.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are more susceptible to disease and damage.

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the cellular membrane in a cell?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide structural support to the cell.

options.label: B
options.text: To act as the doorway into and out of the cell, controlling the exchange of resources and waste.

options.label: C
options.text: To produce energy for the cell through photosynthesis.

options.label: D
options.text: To synthesize proteins and other biomolecules.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the surface area-to-volume ratio of a cell as it increases in size?

options.label: B
options.text: The ratio increases, allowing for more efficient exchange of resources and waste.

options.label: C
options.text: The ratio decreases, limiting the cell's ability to exchange resources and waste.

options.label: D
options.text: The ratio becomes irrelevant, as the cell's size is no longer a limiting factor.

multiple-choice.question: What is an advantage of having multiple smaller cells rather than a single large cell?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased surface area for exchange of resources and waste.

options.label: C
options.text: Improved ability to regulate internal conditions.

options.label: D
options.text: Reduced risk of damage or death if one cell is compromised.

multiple-choice.question: How do some exceptionally large cells, such as neurons, adapt to their size?

options.label: A
options.text: By increasing their surface area through folding or branching.

options.label: B
options.text: By decreasing their metabolic rate to reduce waste production.

options.label: C
options.text: By developing specialized structures to enhance resource exchange.

options.label: D
options.text: By becoming thinner and more elongated to increase their surface area-to-volume ratio.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the structure of Caulerpa taxifolia, a green algae that can reach 30 centimeters long?

options.label: A
options.text: It has a highly folded membrane to increase its surface area.

options.label: B
options.text: It has multiple nuclei, making it similar to a multicellular organism.

options.label: C
options.text: It uses photosynthesis to assemble its own food molecules.

multiple-choice.question: Why are even the largest unicellular organisms limited in their size?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they lack the necessary resources to grow larger.

options.label: B
options.text: Because their surface area and volume increase at different rates, limiting their ability to exchange resources and waste.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are less complex than multicellular organisms.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are more susceptible to disease and damage.

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of microvilli in the small intestine?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the surface area for absorption of nutrients.

options.label: B
options.text: To produce digestive enzymes to break down food.

options.label: C
options.text: To provide structural support to the intestinal lining.

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate the movement of food through the digestive tract.

multiple-choice.question: How do multicellular organisms, such as elephants and whales, achieve their large size?

options.label: A
options.text: By having a single large cell that encompasses their entire body.

options.label: B
options.text: By having multiple smaller cells that work together to form tissues and organs.

options.label: C
options.text: By having a highly efficient system for exchanging resources and waste.

options.label: D
options.text: By having a unique biological hack that allows them to cheat the system.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To explain why unicellular organisms are generally small in size.

options.label: B
options.text: To describe the structure and function of cells in multicellular organisms.

options.label: C
options.text: To compare and contrast unicellular and multicellular organisms.

options.label: D
options.text: To explore the unique characteristics of exceptionally large cells.

title: This Video Will Make You Angry

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind the concept of "thought germs"?

options.label: A
options.text: Thoughts are like living organisms that can spread and evolve.

options.label: B
options.text: Thoughts are like viruses that can harm our brains.

options.label: C
options.text: Thoughts are like emotions that can affect our behavior.

options.label: D
options.text: Thoughts are like ideas that can be shared and discussed.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the most effective way for a thought germ to spread?

According to the transcript, what is the result of thought germs competing with each other?

options.label: B
options.text: They become weaker and less effective.

options.label: D
options.text: They have no effect on each other.

options.text: It becomes more effective and influential.

options.label: B
options.text: It becomes less effective and influential.

options.label: C
options.text: It burns out and loses its impact.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on its influence.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the process of a thought germ becoming more effective and influential as it spreads?

options.label: A
options.text: Emotions have no effect on the spread of thought germs.

options.label: B
options.text: Emotions can hinder the spread of thought germs.

options.label: C
options.text: Emotions can facilitate the spread of thought germs.

options.label: D
options.text: Emotions are the primary driver of the spread of thought germs.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the process of a group constructing a negative image of another group?
According to the transcript, what is the importance of being aware of how thought germs spread and evolve?

options.label: A
options.text: It can help us to create more effective thought germs.

options.label: B
options.text: It can help us to avoid being influenced by thought germs.

options.label: C
options.text: It can help us to maintain a healthy brain and be more critical of information.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no importance or relevance.

title: How to visualize one part per million - Kim Preshoff + The TED-Ed Community

multiple-choice.question: What does "one part per million" (ppm) measure?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of units of one substance per one thousand units of another.

options.label: B
options.text: The number of units of one substance per one million units of another.

options.label: C
options.text: The number of units of one substance per one billion units of another.

options.label: D
options.text: The number of units of one substance per one trillion units of another.

options.text: Because it's a very large number.

title: How a single-celled organism almost wiped out life on Earth - Anusuya Willis

multiple-choice.question: What type of organism changed the world by sending the first free oxygen molecules into the atmosphere?

title: Your words may predict your future mental health

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind Julian Jaynes's theory about human consciousness?

options.label: A
options.text: That human consciousness has always been the same throughout history.

options.label: B
options.text: That human consciousness developed through social transformations.

options.label: C
options.text: That humans were once schizophrenics and only gained introspection 3,000 years ago.

options.label: D
options.text: That human consciousness is not amenable to scientific study.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the problem with Jaynes's theory?

options.label: A
options.text: It is based on too many examples.

options.label: B
options.text: It is not supported by scientific evidence.

options.label: C
options.text: It is built on just a few and very specific examples.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not relevant to modern society.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "space of words" that the speaker refers to?

options.label: A
options.text: A physical space where words are written.

options.label: B
options.text: A mental space where words are thought.

options.label: C
options.text: A computational space where words are analyzed.

options.label: D
options.text: A historical space where words are recorded.

multiple-choice.question: How does the speaker propose to analyze the history of introspection?

options.label: A
options.text: By reading ancient texts and looking for explicit mentions of introspection.

options.label: B
options.text: By analyzing the semantics of words in ancient texts.

options.label: C
options.text: By asking experts about their opinions on introspection.

options.label: D
options.text: By conducting experiments on modern humans.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the speaker's analysis of ancient Greek texts?

options.label: A
options.text: That introspection was present throughout ancient Greek history.

options.label: B
options.text: That introspection developed rapidly around 4 centuries before Christ.

options.label: C
options.text: That introspection was absent in ancient Greek texts.

options.label: D
options.text: That introspection was only present in certain regions of ancient Greece.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of Saint Augustine's writings in the context of the speaker's research?

options.label: A
options.text: They provide evidence against the speaker's theory.

options.label: B
options.text: They provide evidence for the speaker's theory.

options.label: C
options.text: They are irrelevant to the speaker's research.

options.label: D
options.text: They are the only example of introspection in ancient texts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's goal in analyzing the words of people at risk of developing schizophrenia?

options.label: A
options.text: To predict the future onset of psychosis.

options.label: B
options.text: To distinguish between schizophrenics and a control group.

options.label: C
options.text: To understand the causes of schizophrenia.

options.label: D
options.text: To develop a new treatment for schizophrenia.

multiple-choice.question: What is the measure that the speaker and his colleague developed to analyze speech patterns?

options.label: A
options.text: That semantic coherence is not a useful predictor of psychosis.

options.label: B
options.text: That semantic coherence can predict psychosis with 100% accuracy.

options.label: C
options.text: That semantic coherence is only useful for distinguishing between schizophrenics and a control group.

options.label: D
options.text: That semantic coherence is not relevant to schizophrenia.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential application of the speaker's research in the field of mental health?

options.label: A
options.text: Developing new treatments for mental illnesses.

options.label: C
options.text: Creating automated systems for monitoring mental health.
